It seems like you are interested in reviving the form of that argument here - noting a correlation between being trans and some negative mental health outcomes - and declaring that this means we should identify trans behavior as a health risk worth reporting on unto itself.
Putting aside the veracity of the specific statistic, so what if autistic people are more likely to be trans? The former doesn't make the latter more likely to be a mental health symptom.
If you are instead arguing that trans identity is just a manifestation of other mental health concerns, whereas being gay is not, you're way outside of psychology at this point.

It is the case that people who have mental health issues sometimes come out as gay, and they even sometimes describe difficulty with their sexual orientation and broader society as a basis for their mental health struggles.

This has absolutely no connection to anything said above. If people on the autism spectrum are more likely to have a gender identity opposite their anatomical sex than people not on the autism spectrum, it doesn't follow that being trans is a worrying mental health symptom.

Ways mental health of those with TB can be improved
‚Ä¢ Build a peer support system
‚Ä¢ Eat right.
‚Ä¢ Adhere to medication so the recovery process becomes faster.
‚Ä¢ Government should implement a stigma mitigation strategy in communities and for affected individuals and families.

‚Ä¢ Mental health conditions can act as barrier to TB management and eradication. This leads to poor treatment outcomes, decreased compliance which increases the probability of medical issues such as developing multi-drug resistant TB or death, disability and poor quality of life

Impact of Mental health on TB and TB management
‚Ä¢ General psychological distress, depression and anxiety disorders are the most prevalent mental health conditions affecting people with TB.

Other factors that have been identified as risk factor for the prevelance of mental health issues in TB include being female, old age. There is an evidence of increased risk of suicide behavior among people living with TB and those being retreated.

TB acts as a risk factor for mental health conditions including psychological distress, depression and anxiety as a result of duration and side effects of treatment, social stigma attached to the illness, poor social support and reduced quality of life.

IMPACT OF TUBERCULOSIS ON MENTAL HEALTH

Cyberbullying: Social media can be used to bully and harass individuals, leading to mental health problems such as depression and anxiety.
FOMO: Social media can create a fear of missing out on important events or experiences, leading to feelings of inadequacy and low self-esteem

Awareness raising: Social media can be used to raise awareness on important issues and causes.

The Downside of Social Media to Mental Health:

Addiction: Social media can be addictive, leading to excessive use and loss of productivity.
Sleep problems: Social media use before bedtime can disrupt sleep patterns, leading to mental health problems such as depression and anxiety.

Comparison: Social media can lead to unhealthy comparisons with others, leading to negative emotions and mental health problems.

Disinformation: Social media can spread false information, leading to confusion and anxiety.

It's important to recognize that mental health is just as important as physical health and to prioritize it accordingly. This means advocating for policies and programs that improve access to mental health care and support systems, as well as challenging the stigma that still

Prioritizing mental health can have a positive impact on not only individual health and wellbeing but also on society as a whole. Studies have shown that untreated mental illness can lead to increased healthcare costs, reduced productivity, and even higher rates of crime.

Addressing these barriers requires a comprehensive approach that involves not only improving access to mental health care but also addressing the root causes of mental illness, such as poverty, trauma, and discrimination.

Despite the prevalence of mental health issues, many people still face barriers to accessing mental health care. These barriers can include cost, lack of insurance coverage, and stigma surrounding mental illness.

Mental health is a crucial aspect of overall health and wellbeing. According to the National Alliance on Mental Illness (NAMI), 1 in 5 adults in the US experiences mental illness in a given year. This highlights the need to prioritize mental health.

"Dogmas emerge when we avoid complexity."
                                              --Tatiana Bachkirova 

This certainly applies to mental health.

We need to embrace the biopsychosocial complexity of mental illness in order to help people heal and recover.

Assumption 1: Major depression is a valid disorder. It's the same thing today that it was 40 years ago.
